title: Joseph’s Dreams and Betrayal
summary: Genesis 37 introduces Joseph, favored by his father Jacob. Joseph shares dreams of ruling over his family, angering his brothers. They sell him into slavery in Egypt and deceive their father into thinking he is dead.

faq.question: Why did Joseph’s brothers hate him?
faq.answer: Because he was favored by Jacob and shared dreams that implied he would rule over them.

faq.question: What did the brothers do to Joseph?
faq.answer: They threw him into a pit and sold him to Midianite traders heading to Egypt.

faq.question: Why were dreams important in the Bible?
faq.answer: In Bible times, people believed that God often spoke through dreams. Dreams were seen as meaningful messages about the future. When Joseph had dreams, his family took them seriously—even if they didn’t like what the dreams were saying.

faq.question: Why did people tear their clothes when they were upset?
faq.answer: Tearing clothes was a way to show deep sadness, shock, or grief. In ancient cultures, people didn’t hide their emotions. This was a public way to express how heartbroken they felt, especially after hearing really bad news.

faq.question: Why did Joseph’s brothers have to travel with the sheep? Couldn’t they just keep them on their land?
faq.answer: Back then, people didn’t always have fenced-in land like today. They were nomadic shepherds, which means they had to move around to find grass and water for the animals. If the nearby area ran out of food, they had to travel with the sheep to new places.
